title: warfare
comment: The state of being at war with an opposing nation or people. Scripture neither condemns nor glories in warfare, but recognises it as a continuing aspect of this fallen world. In particular, the NT stresses the importance of spiritual warfare in the life of faith.

children.title: warfare, nature of
children.comment: Warfare is characteristic of a fallen world. Scripture describes how some wars are justified and others are not.

children.title: Warfare is characteristic of a fallen world
It is an aspect of life in a fallen world
Warfare as a sign of the end times
Warfare is sometimes a means of judgment
God's will that warfare will finally cease
warfare, examples of
children.comment: From the time of entering the promised land, Israel was obliged to engage in warfare against other nations. Success is attributed to Israel's trust in the LORD and failure to lack of faith and disobedience.

children.title: Israel had to engage in warfare to enter Canaan
Israel failed to drive out the remaining Canaanites

primaryrefs.comment: Judah distrusted God's power to destroy their enemy's iron chariots.

children.title: Israel was obliged to engage in warfare to defend the land
Israel's constant unfaithfulness led to the exile
Judah's constant unfaithfulness led to the Babylonian captivity
warfare, strategies in
children.comment: Scripture describes the strategies employed by Israel in warfare. Although recognising the importance of military preparation, Scripture stresses that Israel's trust is to be in God, rather than military might or prowess.

primaryrefs.comment: The Hebrews divided the night into three watches.

children.title: Of greater importance than military might or prowess
Demonstrated by seeking God before a battle
Strengthened by seeing God fighting for Israel
